content:
Sure, here is an example of how you might include a mediation effect in one of the SEM models from the previous example:
```
# Load the lavaan package
library(lavaan)

# Fit the SEM model to the data
model <- ' 
  # Latent variables
  Anxiety =~ x1 + x2 + x3
  Depression =~ x4 + x5 + x6
  Stress =~ x7 + x8 + x9
  Coping =~ x10 + x11 + x12
  # Covariances
  Anxiety ~~ Depression
  Anxiety ~~ Stress
  Depression ~~ Stress
  # Regressions
  Anxiety ~ Coping
  Depression ~ Coping
'
fit <- sem(model, data = mydata)

# Test the mediation effect of Coping on the relationship between Anxiety and Depression
mediation(fit, mediator = "Coping", dependent = "Depression", independent = "Anxiety")
```
In this example, the SEM model includes a latent variable, Coping, which is assumed to mediate the relationship between Anxiety and Depression. The `mediation()` function can be used to test the significance of the mediation effect and to estimate the direct and indirect effects of Coping on the relationship between Anxiety and Depression.
